dean denounced student government as "a mutual admiration
society with an inflated sense of
self importance."
A recent
interview with Student Council
president Michael Steele began
with the question,"Convince me
there's a reason that the Council
should exist." At best, enthusiasm for student representation

care, if only enough to yell and
complain, and remain eternally
suspicious that the job is not
being done as well as it could be.

ethnic associations, and preprofessional organizations which
add at least a small spot of color

to life at Hopkins--and, of
course, the question of how our
money is being spent on them.

ROTC Cadets Simulate Maneuvres In FTX
BY PETER GODSTON
While you were watching
the Johns Hopkins—U.Va.
lacrosse thriller this past Saturday, eighty Army ROTC
cadets, including some 40
Johns Hopkins students, were
reacting to snipers, ambushes,
artillery simulators(Army-issue
pyrotechnics that whistle, and
then explode, after they are
activated) and the fires that the
simulators started in the dry
underbrush.
The Field Training Exercize (FTX) is an annual Johns
Hopkins Army ROTC event,
organized to provide each
cadet with infantry training
and leadership experience. The
FTX began at noon Friday,
April 3 and ended at about
4:00 p.m. Sunday, .Apri15.
Although many cadets do not
choose to be infantry officers,
opting instead for Service Support branches of the Army
(like the Medical Corps), the
FTX improves the cadets'
chances of doing well at
Advanced Camp, which each
future officer must attend and
pass during the summer between his or her junior and
senior years.
After being assigned to
one of two platoons and issued
four C-rations, a weapon (the
M-16 or the M-60 machine
gun) and two boxes of blank
ammunition (among other
things) the cadets boarded
buses and were taken to Fort
Meade. After brief classes on
individual soldiering skills radio

operations and squad tactics,
the cadets were led by newly
designated cadet leaders to
their respective Night Defensive Positions (NDP's). At each
NDP, the platoons were ambushed by members of an
aggressor force (predominantly
made up of freshmen Ranger
cadets), then settled down for
a delicious (???) C-ration dinner. After dinner there was
instruction on how to dog a
defensive position (popularly
known as a foxhole). Next,
the cadets were paired off by a
new set of cadet leaders and
assigned a place to dig a
defensive position. Although
none of the holes were armpitlevel depth, as specified by the
Army, the camoflauged defensive positions came in handy
later that evening when the
aggressor
force
attacked.
Afterwards, the cadets unrolled
their sleeping bags and slept
under the stars.
Leadership positions were
constantly being changed to
give each cadet a chance to
make mistakes, and, in the
process, learn a great deal.
Tactical situations were set up
Saturday to offer the cadet
leaders constructive criticism
on their decisiveness, enthusiasm, knowledge, confidence,
ability to communicate with
their subordinates, and performace under pressure.
On Sunday, the two platoons were issued scopes for
their M-16's and numbered
cloth covers for their helmets.
With these added items, the

cadets were exposed to a more
realistic battle situation, since
those who exposed themselves
to the enemy long enough to
have their numbers recognized
were exposed long enough to
be shot. Some cadets realized
they had a lot to learn despite
a weekend in the woods, while
other cadets demonstrated the
value of good camoflauge by
thoroughly plastering their
numbers with mud and leaves.
Another highlight of the
FTX was the hot meal served
Saturday night. Although the
food might have been even
worse than that served in the
dorm cafeteria, and an occasional pine needle found its
way into the mashed potatoes,

a meal from Danny's couldn's
have done more for the morale.
Later Saturday night (and
well into Sunday morning) one
of the night patrols found use
for tbis newly found morale.
After maneuvring through
briars, and marching on overgrown dirt road,the "Northern
Parkway Patrol" began to
comb the woods for the enemy
Night
Defensive Position.
After a period of searching,the
patrol open-fired on the trees
and let out enthusiastic battle
cries, hoping to stir something
up. When the enemy still
evaded discovery, enthusiasm
abated. "Where are we?" a
cadet asked. Eventually the
Patrol stumbled on Northern

Parkway, but unfortunately
lost radio contact with the rest
of the ROTC detachment. The
patrol finally returned to camp
at 5:00 a.m., just in time for
breakfast.
On Sunday afternoon, the
cadets cleaned their weapons
and, at last, were dismissed to
go home to showers and beds.
If, while you are studying in
the Hut, you happen to notice
someone covered with scratches, and, perhaps, still sporting
green camoflauge coloring behind his ears, ask about the
FTX. Undoubtedly, you will
hear another war story. For
better or for worse, someone
may have to know how to fight
a war.

Still AngryAfter All These Years
BY MARK TRACHTENBERG
Twelve Angry Men, written back
in the 1950's, is perhaps the classic
American play about what happens in a
criminal case after it goes to the jury.
Author Reginald Rose grapples with the
timeless issues of justice and injustice,
stobbornness and openmindness, bigotry
and tolerance, fear and courage— in short,
whether it is really possible for 12 strangers to reach a rational decision concerning
the guilt or innocence of another human
being. The current production at the
Fells Point Theatre, playing Friday,
Saturday, and Sunday nights through
April 26, highlights the script's many
strengths as well as its few weaknesses.
Rose wastes little time in plunging
us into the heart of the story. A 19-yearold boy is charged with murdering his
often cruel father in their slum apartment. There are two witnesses, so the
case is open-and-shut...or is it? One juror(No.8)
doesn't think so. Resisting pressure from

many of the others, he gradually begins
to persuade some of them. Tempers
often flare. Piece after piece of the
prosecution's evidence is somehow discredited, until at the end only one
juror(No. 3) is left advocating a guilty
verdict, his position backed by nothing
but sheer intransigence.
Any play about 12 people trying
to achieve an agreement must depend
heavily on strong ensemble playing--the
cast working together crisply and with
conviction--and from the first awkward
moments after the jury enters the room,
Al Tyler's solid if somewhat conventional
direction supplies this necessary ingredient. Such incidents as No. 8 picking up
his first convert by secret ballot come
alive because the rest of the cast reacts-so
swiftly and so intensely, suggesting just
how powerful a force conformity can be.
The clear standout among the
individual performances is John Walchi's
beefy, deep-voiced portrayal of the
bullheaded, hot-tempered Juror No. 3,

jury's verdict. The audience's involvement is heightened by the theatre's small

BY PETER GODSTON
While you were watching
the Johns Hopkins—U.Va.
lacrosse thriller this past Saturday, eighty Army ROTC
cadets, including some 40
Johns Hopkins students, were
reacting to snipers, ambushes,
artillery simulators(Army-issue
pyrotechnics that whistle, and
then explode, after they are
activated) and the fires that the
simulators started in the dry
underbrush.
The Field Training Exercize (FTX) is an annual Johns
Hopkins Army ROTC event,
organized to provide each
cadet with infantry training
and leadership experience. The
FTX began at noon Friday,
April 3 and ended at about
4:00 p.m. Sunday, .Apri15.
Although many cadets do not
choose to be infantry officers,
opting instead for Service Support branches of the Army
(like the Medical Corps), the
FTX improves the cadets'
chances of doing well at
Advanced Camp, which each
future officer must attend and
pass during the summer between his or her junior and
senior years.
After being assigned to
one of two platoons and issued
four C-rations, a weapon (the
M-16 or the M-60 machine
gun) and two boxes of blank
ammunition (among other
things) the cadets boarded
buses and were taken to Fort
Meade. After brief classes on
individual soldiering skills radio

operations and squad tactics,
the cadets were led by newly
designated cadet leaders to
their respective Night Defensive Positions (NDP's). At each
NDP, the platoons were ambushed by members of an
aggressor force (predominantly
made up of freshmen Ranger
cadets), then settled down for
a delicious (???) C-ration dinner. After dinner there was
instruction on how to dog a
defensive position (popularly
known as a foxhole). Next,
the cadets were paired off by a
new set of cadet leaders and
assigned a place to dig a
defensive position. Although
none of the holes were armpitlevel depth, as specified by the
Army, the camoflauged defensive positions came in handy
later that evening when the
aggressor
force
attacked.
Afterwards, the cadets unrolled
their sleeping bags and slept
under the stars.
Leadership positions were
constantly being changed to
give each cadet a chance to
make mistakes, and, in the
process, learn a great deal.
Tactical situations were set up
Saturday to offer the cadet
leaders constructive criticism
on their decisiveness, enthusiasm, knowledge, confidence,
ability to communicate with
their subordinates, and performace under pressure.
On Sunday, the two platoons were issued scopes for
their M-16's and numbered
cloth covers for their helmets.
With these added items, the

cadets were exposed to a more
realistic battle situation, since
those who exposed themselves
to the enemy long enough to
have their numbers recognized
were exposed long enough to
be shot. Some cadets realized
they had a lot to learn despite
a weekend in the woods, while
other cadets demonstrated the
value of good camoflauge by
thoroughly plastering their
numbers with mud and leaves.
Another highlight of the
FTX was the hot meal served
Saturday night. Although the
food might have been even
worse than that served in the
dorm cafeteria, and an occasional pine needle found its
way into the mashed potatoes,

a meal from Danny's couldn's
have done more for the morale.
Later Saturday night (and
well into Sunday morning) one
of the night patrols found use
for tbis newly found morale.
After maneuvring through
briars, and marching on overgrown dirt road,the "Northern
Parkway Patrol" began to
comb the woods for the enemy
Night
Defensive Position.
After a period of searching,the
patrol open-fired on the trees
and let out enthusiastic battle
cries, hoping to stir something
up. When the enemy still
evaded discovery, enthusiasm
abated. "Where are we?" a
cadet asked. Eventually the
Patrol stumbled on Northern

Parkway, but unfortunately
lost radio contact with the rest
of the ROTC detachment. The
patrol finally returned to camp
at 5:00 a.m., just in time for
breakfast.
On Sunday afternoon, the
cadets cleaned their weapons
and, at last, were dismissed to
go home to showers and beds.
If, while you are studying in
the Hut, you happen to notice
someone covered with scratches, and, perhaps, still sporting
green camoflauge coloring behind his ears, ask about the
FTX. Undoubtedly, you will
hear another war story. For
better or for worse, someone
may have to know how to fight
a war.
